structured_info.title_cn: 车载安全网络开放模拟器（VESNOS）：面向网联自动驾驶的网络安全协同仿真平台
structured_info.title_en: VEhicular Secure Network Open Simulator (VESNOS): A Cyber-security oriented co-simulation platform for connected and automated driving
structured_info.abstract: Connected vehicles are a big part of the automotive industry's overall growth trend that may be utilized to improve transportation safety, expand mobility options, lower expenses, and provide new job possibilities. Thus, a complete examination of connected driving is required before the large-scale implementation in reality, which may be done affordably and efficiently using a reliable simulation platform. Current traffic simulators ease the research and development of connected vehicles by offering incremental enhancements to traditional traffic flow modeling approaches, which cannot replicate the features of real-world connected vehicles. Moreover, current standard security features that are used by the U.S. Department of Transportation or other research entities are not considered. Network-level evaluation incorporating large-scale traffic networks and Vehicle-To-Everything (V2X) communications should also be addressed. This study develops a novel and comprehensive co-simulation platform for conventional, connected, and automated driving that tightly integrates the main components of V2X communications, cyber-security protocol, traffic networks, and conventional vehicle models. Three major open-source components, SUMO, OMNeT++, and security credential management system (SCMS) based V2X simulator, are integrated and interconnected via the Traffic Control Interface (TraCI). Case studies show that the proposed platform provides an appropriate and trustworthy testbed for examining the possible social economic effects of connected driving under a security credential management system.
structured_info.methodology: Integration of SUMO (traffic microsimulation), OMNeT++ (network simulation), and SCMS (Security Credential Management System) via bidirectional coupling using TraCI (Traffic Control Interface). Client-server deployment model with real-time synchronization of vehicle positions, V2X communications, and security authentication protocols.
structured_info.conclusion: VESNOS provides an efficient and trustworthy testbed for evaluating cybersecurity in connected vehicles. It successfully detects man-in-the-middle attacks within 52ms and prevents Sybil attacks in platooning scenarios through SCMS authentication. The platform demonstrates significant improvements in attack detection speed compared to existing frameworks, validating its effectiveness for secure V2X communication analysis.
structured_info.venue: 38th ACM SIGSIM Conference on Principles of Advanced Discrete Simulation (SIGSIM PADS '24)

analysis.Overview: Presents VESNOS, a co-simulation platform integrating traffic dynamics (SUMO), V2X communications (OMNeT++), and cybersecurity protocols (SCMS) to evaluate connected/automated vehicles under realistic attack scenarios.
Background_and_Motivation: Lack of existing simulators incorporating USDOT's Security Credential Management System (SCMS) standards for vehicular security
Need for integrated evaluation of cyber-physical interactions in large-scale vehicular networks with security guarantees
Urgent requirement due to vulnerabilities in V2X communication enabling attacks (e.g., Sybil, man-in-the-middle) with safety implications
Connects simulator limitations to broader challenges in secure CAV deployment, emphasizing SCMS as industry-adopted solution
Transportation engineering, computer networks, cybersecurity, discrete event simulation
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Co-simulation: Bidirectional coupling of traffic/network simulators via TraCI
SCMS: PKI-based certificate management for message authentication
Bidirectional Coupling: Real-time synchronization affecting both traffic behavior and network events
SCMS ensures trust in V2X data → influences vehicle control decisions in SUMO → alters network communication patterns in OMNeT++
Vehicles follow predefined mobility models; attackers compromise V2X messages; SCMS provides perfect authentication
Novel tool contribution: First open-source platform integrating USDOT's SCMS standard for vehicular security evaluation
Methodology: Bidirectional TraCI coupling between SUMO (traffic) and OMNeT++ (network), SCMS for certificate-based BSM authentication
Novelty: First SCMS-integrated simulator; Applicability: Client-server deployment; Rationality: Aligns with USDOT security standards
Simulated data from SUMO/OMNeT++; Preprocessing: Vehicle kinematics→BSM generation→SCMS signing; Representativeness: Models real-world VANET parameters
Rigorous case studies (Sybil/man-in-middle attacks) with metrics: detection time, speed deviation, fuel impact; Adequate metrics cover security/performance
Cyber-physical systems paradigm: Integrates physical dynamics with cyber threats, enabling holistic vulnerability analysis
Results: SCMS detects man-in-middle attacks in 52ms; BSM signing completes in <0.01s; Sybil attacks cause 40% speed reduction without SCMS
Results significant for real-time security (10Hz BSM frequency); Reliability validated via reproducible attack scenarios; Stability consistent across platoon sizes
Argumentation_and_Logic: 1. Simulator limitations 2. SCMS necessity 3. Platform integration 4. Attack vulnerability demonstration 5. SCMS efficacy proof
Strength: Empirical validation; Weakness: Limited attack types tested; Rebuttals addressed via comparison to baseline (no SCMS)
Strengths_and_Limitations: First SCMS-integrated open-source simulator; Real-time attack detection; Bidirectional physical-cyber interactions
Dependent on SUMO/OMNeT++ fidelity; Computational scalability unverified; No hardware-in-loop validation
Cyber-physical paradigm overlooks human behavior aspects; SCMS focus limits exploration of alternative security models
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Advances vehicular security simulation discourse by bridging USDOT standards with academic research tools
Technical terminology (e.g., BSM, PKI, TraCI); Persuasive tone emphasizing SCMS adoption; Rhetoric contrasts 'inadequate' existing tools with VESNOS' comprehensiveness
Cites USDOT standards and foundational simulators (SUMO/OMNeT++) to establish authority; Motivation: Legitimize platform via industry alignment
Conclusions_and_Implications: VESNOS enables realistic cybersecurity evaluation for CAVs; SCMS integration reduces attack impact by 95+%; Platform publicly available
Expand attack models; Integrate sensor simulations; Test federated learning defenses; Optimize computational efficiency
